title: About Me!
text: Hi, I’m Sose and I’m a senior at the University of Pennsylvania, majoring in Communication with a concentration in data and network science. I also have minors in consumer psychology and history and plan on a career in corporate communications and marketing. I’m excited to show off what I’ve learned in my COMM data and network science classes thus far in the blog posts below!

title: Dataset of the Week 1 - The Weather in Philadelphia
text:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd


weather_df = pd.read_csv('philadelphia_weather_2005_to_2025.csv')

As we can see here, in the last 21 years, it has rained 6 times on February 27th. Let’s see if of those 6 times, three of them truly were during my college years:

it_rained = feb27['rain']>0
feb27[it_rained]

February









Aha! In my time at Penn (Aug 2022 - Present), it has in fact rained on my birthday every year!


Seems like the weather gods decided to take a year off in 2022, breaking up the streak from 2020-2025.


If only I had been born ten years earlier… would’ve seen blue skies and birthday smiles! Guess I am just cursed (just kidding)!


But how do we know this?

The steps taken via code are not all that different from what we would’ve done with a dataset by hand! The steps are actually rather simple:

First, we filter for the February 27 dates in the ‘day’ column of the dataset
Then, we access the ‘rain’ column to see if it rained or not. How do we know? If the listed number is > 0, it rained!
Next, we count down the ‘rain’ column for the days with > 0.0 rain
Finally, we concur: 6 recorded days of rain on February 27th in the last 21 years!

One day more than Feb!

I guess being born a month later really doesn’t help much at all! If anything, it might be worse in terms of rain! However, I did selfishly notice only 2023 and 2024 of my college experience had recorded rain on March 27th, one less time than my true birthday.

title: Dataset of the Week 1 - The Weather in Philadelphia
section: Oh well, at least it doesn’t snow… right?!?!?!
text:
Oh well, at least it doesn’t snow… right?!?!?!

Let’s double check just to be sure…

it_snowed = feb27['snow']>0
feb27[it_snowed]

PHEW. No Snow.


Thanks for tuning in to my weather journey! If only the code could predict whether it’ll rain on my birthday this year! I guess only time will tell…

title: My first post
text:
Hey everyone - Sose here! Welcome to my blog! Here I will be documenting a number of stories told by data. I am super interested in journalism and this is my first time engaging with data-driven storytelling. Buckle up for the ride ahead!


Numbers are everywhere. We may not immediately see a story when we see endless lists or charts of numbers, but they always tell a story! Throughout this semester, we will work together to learn how to extract impactful, important stories out of seemingly meaningless datasets.

title: My first post
text:
Hey everyone - Sose here! Welcome to my blog! Here I will be documenting a number of stories told by data. I am super interested in journalism and this is my first time engaging with data-driven storytelling. Buckle up for the ride ahead!


Numbers are everywhere. We may not immediately see a story when we see endless lists or charts of numbers, but they always tell a story! Throughout this semester, we will work together to learn how to extract impactful, important stories out of seemingly meaningless datasets.

title: Dataset of the Week 2 - The Big 5 Test
text:
We took the Big 5 Personality Test in our class and these are the results I got!


import pandas as pd
import re
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from IPython.display import display


big5_df = pd.read_csv('openpsych_data.csv', sep='\t')


big5_df.columns

Index(['race', 'age', 'engnat', 'gender', 'hand', 'source', 'country', 'E1',
       'E2', 'E3', 'E4', 'E5', 'E6', 'E7', 'E8', 'E9', 'E10', 'N1', 'N2', 'N3',
       'N4', 'N5', 'N6', 'N7', 'N8', 'N9', 'N10', 'A1', 'A2', 'A3', 'A4', 'A5',
       'A6', 'A7', 'A8', 'A9', 'A10', 'C1', 'C2', 'C3', 'C4', 'C5', 'C6', 'C7',
       'C8', 'C9', 'C10', 'O1', 'O2', 'O3', 'O4', 'O5', 'O6', 'O7', 'O8', 'O9',
       'O10'],
      dtype='str')



gender_map = {
    0: pd.NA,
    1: 'male',
    2: 'female',
    3: 'other'
}


big5_df['gender'].value_counts()

gender
2    11985
1     7608
3      102
0       24
Name: count, dtype: int64



big5_df=big5_df.assign(gender_cat=big5_df['gender'].map(gender_map))


big5_df['gender_cat'].value_counts()

gender_cat
female    11985
male       7608
other       102
Name: count, dtype: int64


curiosu about relationship between scores agreeableness –> neurotocism? does anyone else have this pattern? high in one, low in another eyeball class data look at 20,000 person full dataset, then we can start to really ask that question

big5_df['country'].value_counts().head(20)

Name: count, dtype: int64

title: Dataset of the Week 2 - The Big 5 Test
text:
We took the Big 5 Personality Test in our class and these are the results I got!


import pandas as pd
import re
import numpy as np

big5_df.columns
